questions.text: Consider the following barium swallow finding in a patient of dysphagia. Manometry in this patient will show_________

choices.text: Decreased amplitude of oesophageal peristalsis <30 mmHg
Peristaltic oesophageal contractions 2 standard deviations above normal

questions.solution:
The barium swallow image shows corkscrew oesophagus seen in diffuse oesophageal spasm. Manometry in diffuse oesophageal spasm will show simultaneous multipeak contractions >120mmHg.

Diffuse oesophageal spasm:

  • Barium swallow: Corkscrew or rosary-bead esophagus, segmental spasm or pseudodiverticulosis appearance is seen. It is due to the presence of tertiary contractions. It is indicative of advanced disease.
  • Manometry findings: Simultaneous, multipeaked contractions of high amplitude (>120 mm Hg) or long duration (>2.5 sec). These erratic contractions occur after more than 20% of wet swallows. There is intermittent normal peristalsis.

Related Pearl: Manometric classification of esophageal motility disorders

Types Definition

DCI (distal contractile integral) is an index of contractile vigor and is calculated as the product of amplitude, duration, and span of the distal esophageal contraction, (mmHg·s·cm).

IRP (integrated relaxation pressure) corresponds to the mean pressure of greatest post deglutitive relaxation in a 10 seconds gap, triggered at the beginning of a swallow, (mmHg).

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presented with dysphagia and postprandial chest pain. A barium swallow image is shown below. Which of the following statements is true regarding the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: It is associated with hiatus hernia
Most commonly seen in middle third of esophagus

questions.solution:
The given barium swallow showing a thin submucosal circumferential ring at the squamocolumnar junction is suggestive of Schatzki's ring. The true statement regarding the condition is, that it is associated with hiatus hernia.

Schatzki’s ring is a thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction. Schatzki's ring is a non-malignant condition and is often associated with a hiatal hernia. The patient experiences brief episodes of dysphagia during the hurried ingestion of solid foods.

The presence of a ring in the esophagus, with or without hiatal hernia, can be visualized on barium swallow.

For symptomatic patients who do not have reflux, the best form of treatment consists of esophageal dilation for relief of the obstructive symptoms. In patients who have proven reflux and a mechanically defective sphincter, an antireflux procedure is done to obtain relief and avoid repeated dilation.

Related Pearl: Barium swallow

Diffuse esophageal spasm: Corkscrew appearance

Feline esophagus: Transient transverse bands seen in the mid and lower esophagus on a double-contrast barium swallow. It is seen in active gastroesophageal reflux, hiatus hernia, and eosinophilic esophagitis.

Achalasia: Dilated esophagus with a retained column of barium and bird beak sign.

Zenker's diverticulum: Posterior outpouching of the hypopharynx through a weakness in the muscle layer called Killian dehiscence.

Esophageal carcinoma: Irregular narrowing, mucosal destruction, and shouldered margins.

Schatzki's ring: Thin submucosal circumferential ring in the lower esophagus at the squamocolumnar junction.

Esophageal web in a patient with Plummer Vinson syndrome. Esophageal webs are thin membranes of normal esophageal tissue consisting of mucosa and submucosa. Translucent part denotes esophageal web.

Esophageal leiomyoma is the most common benign tumor of the esophagus. On barium swallow, it is seen as a discrete ovoid mass that is well outlined by barium (smooth submucosal mass). Its borders form slightly obtuse angles with the esophagal wall.

The image below depicts a barium study showing the classic semilunar filling defect.

questions.text: Gastrointestinal stromal tumours express all except_____________
questions.solution:
Gastrointestinal stromal tumours(GIST) express C-KIT, PDGF receptor A and CD34 but do not express desmin and actin.

All smooth muscle tumors express actin and desmin but do not express C-KIT, PDGF receptor A and CD 34.

Related Pearl: Gastrointestinal Stromal Tumor (GIST)

M/C mesenchymal tumor of GIT arising from interstitial cells of Cajal (pacemaker cells of GIT). Stomach is the m/c site.

GISTs express:

  • c-KIT (CD117)
  • PDGF receptor A
  • CD34
  • SDH

Clinical Features:

  • Peaks at 60 years of age.
  • M/C symptom: Upper GI bleeding
  • Other symptoms: Pain, lump, perforation, incidental finding
  • Carney's Triad: Sporadic GIST, Paraganglioma, Pulmonary chondroma

Management:

  • IOC for primary GIST: CECT abdomen
  • IOC for recurrent GIST: PET-CT
  • IHC markers: CD117/C-KIT (M/C), DOG 1 (most specific), CD 34
  • Route of metastasis: Hematogenous

The following image shows microscopy of GIST composed of spindle-shaped tumor cells:

  • Fletcher's classification (Tumor size & No. of mitotic figures) is used to classify the tumors according to their malignancy risk.
  • Prognosis is determined by: Mitotic index, tumor size & location of tumor (Stomach GISTs are less aggressive).
  • Complete surgical resection is the mainstay treatment. For unresectable, recurrent, or metastatic GISTs, imatinib, a tyrosine kinase inhibitor, can be used.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a risk factor for stomach carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Aspirin is not a risk factor for stomach carcinoma. COX-2 is implicated in causation of gastric cancer. Hence, aspirin which is a COX inhibitor is protective.

Adenomatus polyp, hyperplastic polyp and menetrier’s disease are risk factors for stomach carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

questions.text: Glasgow-Blatchford score _________

choices.text: Assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality.
Screens for the need of medical intervention in UGI bleed.
Classifies the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers.
Gives anatomic description of the tumour location and extension in biliary tree.

questions.solution:
Glasgow-Blatchford score screens for the need of medical intervention in UGI bleed.

Glasgow-Blatchford score: It is a screening tool to assess the likelihood that a patient with an acute upper gastrointestinal bleeding (UGIB) will need to have medical intervention such as a blood transfusion or endoscopic intervention. It incorporates the patient’s blood urea, haemoglobin, blood pressure, and other clinical parameters.

Other options:

  • Rockall Score assesses the risk of rebleeding and in-hospital mortality in patients with upper GI bleed.
  • The Forrest classification is used for classifying the endoscopic appearance of bleeding peptic ulcers. It stratifies the risk of rebleeding based on observed stigmata of recent haemorrhage.
  • The Bismuth–Corlette classification system provides an anatomic description of the tumour location and longitudinal extension in the biliary tree.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presented with a hernia which is palpable below the inguinal ligament lateral to the pubic tubercle.  According to the NYHUS classification system, to which type does this hernia belong?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a femoral hernia. According to the NYHUS classification system, femoral hernia belongs to type III.  

Femoral hernia is distinguished from inguinal hernia by the pubic tubercle. Femoral hernia is palpable below the inguinal ligament and lateral to pubic tubercle while inguinal hernia is palpable above the inguinal ligament and medial to the pubic tubercle. They occur through a defect in the femoral ring.

A femoral hernia will pass through the femoral ring proximally. The posterior border of the femoral ring is formed by the pectineal ligament.

Relations of the femoral ring:

  • Anterior border by the inguinal ligament
  • Posterior border by the
    • Pectineal ligament
    • Superior ramus of the pubic bone
    • Pectineus muscle
  • Medial border by the lacunar ligament
  • Lateral border by the femoral vein  

The incidence of strangulation in femoral hernias is high because of the narrowness of the neck of the sac and rigidity of the femoral ring. Diagnosis is usually made by physical examination and clinical assessment. However, in doubtful cases, Ultrasound abdomen, CT abdomen, or MRI can be done. 

Related Pearl: Nyhus classification of groin hernia

  • Type I - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring normal (e.g., pediatric hernia)
  • Type II - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated but posterior inguinal wall intact; inferior deep epigastric vessels not displaced
  • Type III - Posterior wall defect
    • A- Direct inguinal hernia
    • B - Indirect inguinal hernia: internal inguinal ring dilated, medially encroaching on or destroying the transversalis fascia of Hesselbach triangle (e.g., scrotal, sliding, or pantaloon hernia)
    • C - Femoral hernia
  • Type IV - Recurrent hernia
    • A - Direct
    • B - Indirect
    • C - Femoral
    • D - Combined

Related Pearl: Variants of femoral hernia

Laugier’s femoral hernia:

  • Through a gap in lacunar (Gimbernat) ligament.
  • Always strangulated

Narath’s femoral hernia:

  • Seen in patients with congenital dislocation of hip
  • It is behind the femoral vessels

Cloquet’s hernia:

  • Sac lies under pectineus fascia.

Hesselbach’s hernia:

  • Lateral to femoral artery

Serafini's hernia:

  • Behind the femoral vessels

Velpeau(Prevascular/Teale's) hernia:

  • Infront of femoral vessels

Beclard’s hernia:

  • Through saphenous opening

Related Pearl: Anatomy of Femoral Canal

questions.text: Which of the following hernia is found in fossa of Landzert?
questions.solution:
Mesocolic (paraduodenal) hernia: Mesocolic hernias are unuasual congenital hernias in which the small intestine herniates behind the mesocolon.

  • Left sided paraduodenal hernia is found in fossa of Landzert.
  • Right sided paraduodenal hernia is found in fossa of Kolb.

Other options:

  • Richter hernia: A small portion of the antimesenteric wall of the intestine is trapped within the hernia.
  • Maydl’s hernia/Hernia-en-W/retrograde hernia: Two loops of bowel remain in the sac with the connecting loop inside the abdomen.
  • Mesenteric hernia:  Mesenteric hernias occur when the intes­tine herniates through an abnormal orifice in the mesentery of the small intestine or colon.

questions.text: Most sensitive investigation for small bowel tumours is__________
questions.solution:
Enteroclysis is the most sensitive investigation for small bowel tumours. It has a sensitivity of over 90% in the detection of small bowel tumors and is the test of choice, particularly for tumors located in the distal small bowel.

Advantages: 

  • The contrast is administered at a controlled rate directly in the small bowel bypassing the regulatory action of pylorus.
  • The entire small bowel is demonstrated in a distended state allowing better diagnosis. As a result of the dilatation, mild strictures, small sinus tracts and fistulas, and minimal extrinsic compressions can be visualized besides better delineation of skip lesions and the proximal and distal extent of diffuse diseases.
  • The examination can be completed in 15-30 minutes, thus reducing patient waiting time.

Note:

Among the options, enteroclysis is the best option.But video capsule endoscopy>enteroclysis is the most sensitive investigation.

questions.text: Kantor string sign on barium study maybe seen in cases of __________
questions.solution:
Kantor string sign maybe seen in a barium study of crohn’s disease.

Barium study findings of crohn’s disease:

  • Cobblestone appearance of the mucosa composed of linear ulcers, transverse sinuses and clefts.
  • Kantor string sign: Long lengths of narrowed terminal ileum seen in long-standing disease Segmental and irregular patterns of bowel involvement
  • Fistulas between adjacent bowel loops and organs.

Note: Kantor string sign is suggestive of crohn’s disease. However, a string sign may also be seen in carcinoid tumour and intestinal TB.

questions.text: Which among the following is most likely to be seen as a late post-operative complication after an appendectomy operation?
questions.solution:
Most common late postoperative complication of appendicectomy is adhesive intestinal obstruction.

Wound infection is the most common postoperative complication of appendicectomy.

Intra-abdominal abscess and post-operative ileus are early complications seen after an appendectomy.

Related Pearl: Complications of Appendicectomy

  • Wound infection: 5–10%
  • Intra-abdominal abscess: 8%
  • Post operative ileus
  • Respiratory complications
  • Venous thrombo-embolism
  • Portal pyemia- septicemia in portal venous system, can lead to hepatic abscess.
  • Adhesive intestinal obstruction: 1–3% (MC late post op complication)
  • Fecal fistula
  • Port site hernias.
  • Appendico-cutaneous fistula or appendico-vesical fistula: rare
  • Mortality after appendicectomy is less than 1%

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presented with intermittent upper abdominal pain, episodic hot flushes involving the face and upper chest, and watery stools. Urinalysis was positive for 5-OH indole acetic acid. He was diagnosed to have a carcinoid tumor in the appendix which was 2.5 cm at the tip of the appendix. What is the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
Carcinoid tumors measuring >2 cm should be managed with hemicolectomy.

The carcinoid tumors are neuroendocrine tumors arising from enterochromaffin cells that can occur anywhere in the GIT. The most common site is the appendix followed by the ileum and rectum.

Abdominal symptoms include Abdominal pain, distension, and Lower GI bleeding.

A carcinoid tumor with metastasis to the liver is likely to produce carcinoid syndrome. Metastasis in these patients can cause increased production of serotonin leading to carcinoid syndrome with features like:

  • Flushing
  • Diarrhea
  • Bronchospasm
  • Cardiac symptoms because of stenosis and insufficiency of the cardiac valves

The diagnosis is made by an assessment of 5-hydroxy indole acetic acid (5-HIAA) in a 24-hour urine sample. It is positive in larger tumors only if metastases are present.

Related Pearl: Carcinoid syndrome

questions.text: What is the most common site of diverticulitis?
questions.solution: Sigmoid colon is the most common site of diverticulitis.

questions.text: All are true statements about ischaemic colitis except___________

choices.text: Partial thickness ischaemia includes mucosa and submucosa

questions.solution:
Thumbprinting sign refers to the plain radiographic appearance of the submucosal thickening with its crescentic margins. It is specific for ischemia but is not diagnostic. It is seen in cases of ischaemic colitis and pseudomembranous colitis.

Other options:

  • Partial thickness ischaemia includes mucosa. Sometimes submucosa is also involved.
  • Rectum is rarely involved because of its dual blood supply. It receives blood from IMA through superior haemorrhoidal artey. And from iliac circula­tion, through inferior and middle hemorrhoidal branches.
  • Risk factors:
    • Occlusive cause e.g thromboembolism
    • > 65years
    • COPD 
    • cardiac arrhythmias
    • irri­table bowel syndrome
    • constipation

questions.text: Haggitt’s classification describes carcinoma invading neck of the polyp as level___________
questions.solution: Haggitt’s classification describes carcinoma invading neck of the polyp as level 2.

questions.text: Earliest mutation in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence of colorectal carcinoma occurs in _____
questions.solution:
Earliest mutation in the adenoma-carcinoma sequence of colorectal carcinoma occurs in APC gene. The earliest phenotypic change present is known as aberrant crypt formation.

Related Pearl: Fearon-Vogelstein adenoma-carcinoma multistep model of colorectal neoplasia

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest and most common symptom in patients with rectal carcinoma?
questions.solution:
The most common and earliest symptom in carcinoma rectum patients is the passage of fresh blood in or with stools.

Other symptoms include tenesmus, mucoid discharge, and altered bowel habits. The bleeding is usually bright red in colour and painless. It can be indistinguishable from haemorrhoidal bleeding, which is the most common differential diagnosis, particularly in younger patients.

Adenocarcinoma is the most common variant of rectal carcinoma.

Symptoms of rectal carcinoma include:

  • Bleeding
  • Mucus drainage
  • Tenesmus
  • Early morning diarrhoea
  • Pain
  • Weight loss

Modified Duke’s staging for rectal carcinoma:

A

Growth limited up to the rectal mucosa

B

B1: Tumor invading muscularis propria, no lymph node invasion.

B2: Tumors invading into or through serosa, no lymph node invasion.

C

C1: The tumour did not exceed the bowel wall, lymph node metastasis.

C2: Tumour exceeded the intestinal wall and lymph node metastasis.

D

Distant metastasis

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with CA rectum. The tumour is found to invade through muscularis propria into subserosa. There was no lymph node enlargement and no metastatsis. The appropriate modality of treatment in this patient will be___________
questions.solution:
In the above clinical picture, the TNM staging falls under:

  • The tumour is found to invade through muscularis propria into subserosa– T3
  • No lymph node involvement – N0
  • No evidence of metastasis – M0

So, staging is Stage IIA. Therefore, treatment modality is preoperative chemoradiation followed by radical resection.

questions.text: A 60-year-old man presents with internal hemorrhoid with spontaneously reducing prolapse. What is the appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Internal hemorrhoids with spontaneously reducing prolapse (grade 2) can be managed with rubber band ligation.

Hemorrhoids are cushions of submucosal tissue containing venules, arterioles, and smooth muscle fibers that are located in the anal canal. They can be classified according to their location into 2 types:

  • Internal hemorrhoids 
  • External hemorrhoids

External hemorrhoids are distal to the dentate line and are covered with anoderm; these may engorge causing pain. Thrombosis of these external hemorrhoids causes severe pain. Internal hemorrhoids are characterized by bright red, painless bleeding, or prolapse.

Internal hemorrhoids are stratified into four grades as follows:

GRADE

SYMPTOMS AND SIGNS

First degree

Bleeding; no prolapse

Second degree

Prolapse with spontaneous reduction

Third degree

Prolapse requiring manual reduction

Fourth degree

Prolapsed, cannot be reduced

Management of external hemorrhoids: 

External hemorrhoids do not require treatment unless they become thrombosed. Acutely thrombosed external hemorrhoids cause intense pain and perianal mass during the first 24 to 72 hours. Patients who present within 72 hours of thrombosis are treated with elliptical excision performed under local anesthesia.

If the patient presents to the hospital after 72 hours, then it is treated conservatively with analgesics and a sitz bath. Once the symptoms come down, definitive surgery is performed. 

Management of internal hemorrhoids:

Bleeding from grade 1 and grade 2 hemorrhoids often improves with the addition of dietary fiber, stool softeners, increased fluid intake, and avoidance of straining.

Grade 1, grade 2, and some grade 3 hemorrhoids with only an internal component can be treated with simple procedures like rubber band ligation, sclerotherapy, infrared and laser coagulation, and cryotherapy.

Rubber band ligation involves pulling mucosa located 1 to 2 cm proximal to the dentate line into a rubber band applier. The rubber band strangulates the underlying tissue, causing scarring and sloughing off of the mass in a few days. 

Sclerotherapy involves injecting 1 to 3 mL of a sclerosing solution (phenol in olive oil, sodium morrhuate, or quinine urea) into the submucosa of internal hemorrhoids.

Surgery is indicated in: 

  1. Internal grade 3 or grade 4 hemorrhoids
  2. Hemorrhoids with a significant external component
  3. Early-grade hemorrhoids not responding to simple procedures

Surgical procedures used in the removal of internal hemorrhoids are:

1) Doppler-guided hemorrhoidal artery ligation

2) Open hemorrhoidectomy- the artery forceps are applied to the skin-covered external components of the hemorrhoid and traction is given to reveal the internal components. Dissection of the lateral pedicle is performed and finally, the pedicles are transfixed. Mucocutaneous bridges are left intact in this technique. The image below shows the procedure. 

3) Closed (Ferguson) hemorrhoidectomy- the hemorrhoid is excised with the overlying mucosa. The hemorrhoid is dissected from the underlying sphincter and the mucus defect is then closed. The image below describes the procedure.

4) Stapled hemorrhoidopexy (Longo operation)- the hemorrhoids are pulled up and a purse-string suture is placed a few centimeters above the dentate line. Then, a circumferential rectal mucosectomy is performed using a circular stapler. This technique is associated with higher chances of recurrence, however, it is quick to perform, less painful, and less traumatic. The image below shows stapled hemorrhoidopexy.

Related Pearl: Differences between internal and external hemorrhoids

Located proximal to the dentate line

Located distal to the dentate line
Covered by transitional and columnar epithelium Covered by richly innervated squamous epithelium
Caused by pressure on superior rectal veins Caused by pressure on inferior rectal veins
Painless, can be ligated Painful, not ligated
Banding is preferred Excision is done

questions.text: Overwhelming post splenectomy infection is most commonly seen _______
questions.solution:
Overwhelming post splenectomy infection is most commonly seen after 2-5 years.

Related Pearl: Overwhelming Post-splenectomy Infection (OPSI)

It is the most common fatal infection following splenectomy. 

Certain components called opsonins attach to the encapsulated organisms, and then they are delivered to the spleen, where their uptake is facilitated by receptors present on the surface of splenic phagocytes. After splenectomy, this defence mechanism is lost leaving patients susceptible to infection from these bacteria.

Most common within 2-3 years following splenectomy. 

Causative agents: Usually capsulated organisms like

  • Streptococcus pneumoniae (Most common)
  • Haemophilus influenzae
  • Neisseria meningitidis
  • Streptococcus species
  • Salmonella species
  • Capnocytophaga canimorsus, implicated in OPSI as a result of dog bites

Clinical features

  • Prodromal features like fever, chills, sore throat, malaise, diarrhea, and vomiting
  • Rapid progression to hypotension, disseminated intravascular coagula­tion, respiratory distress, coma, and death within hours of presen­tation
  • High-grade bacteremia with no identifiable foci of infection
  • Poor response to antibiotics

If an elective splenectomy is planned, prophylactic vaccinations against pneumococcus, meningococcus C (both repeated every 5 years), and H. influenzae type B (Hib) must be given atleast 2 weeks before the elective surgery.

In case of an emergency splenectomy, patients should be vaccinated as soon as possible after recovery from surgery but before discharge from the hospital.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication for puncture aspiration injection reaspiration(PAIR) of hydatid cyst?
questions.solution:
Infected cyst is not a contraindication for puncture aspiration injection reaspiration(PAIR) of hydatid cyst. It is an indication for PAIR.

Related Pearl: Indications and contraindications of puncture, aspiration, injection, and re-aspiration (PAIR) in hydatid cyst

Indications:

  • Relapse cyst, infected cyst, cyst >5 cm in different liver segments
  • Patients who refuse surgery or where surgery is contraindicated
  • Pregnant women, children < 3 years of age
  • WHO - type CE1 and type CE3a (transitional cyst)

Contraindications:

  • Cysts in lung
  • Cysts communicating with bile duct
  • Cysts with multiple septae—honeycomb cysts
  • Inaccessible cysts
  • Hyperechogenic cysts
  • Calcified cysts

questions.text: All are true statements regarding budd chiari syndrome except__________

choices.text: It is obstruction of hepatic vein
CECT abdomen is the best investigation
Side to side porto caval shunt is a treatment modality.

questions.solution:
Hepatic venography is the best investigation for budd chiari syndrome (not CECT abdomen).

Budd chiari syndrome: Uncommon congestive hepatopathy characterized by the obstruction of hepatic venous outflow. Most common presentation is ascites and abdominal discomfort.

Investigations:

  • Abdominal ultrasonography with color Doppler is the initial investigation of choice and can demonstrate the absence of hepatic vein flow, spider web hepatic veins, and collateral hepatic veins.
  • The definitive radiographic study is hepatic venography to determine the presence and extent of hepatic vein thrombus as well as measure IVC pressures.

Treatment :

  • Initial treatment is medical management with systemic anticoagulation. The associated portal hypertension and ascites is managed in a manner similar to that in most cirrhotic patients.
  • Radiologic and surgical intervention is used when patient is nonresponsive to medical therapy. Percutaneous angioplasty and TIPS, in combination with thrombolytic therapy, are the preferred strategies to restore the outflow of blood from the liver. Surgical shunting namely with the side-to-side portacaval shunt, turns the portal vein into a hepatic outflow tract.

questions.text: The image given below depicts choledochal cyst type________
questions.solution:
The image depicts choledochal cyst type III.


Choledochal cyst type III : A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Choledochal cysts:

Choledochal cysts are congenital cystic dilations of the intrahepatic and/or extrahepatic biliary tree. They present with a triad of jaundice, a palpable upper quadrant mass, and abdominal pain. They are commonly seen in girls. 

Choledochal cyst is classified into five types:

The original classification for choledochal cysts by Alonso–Lej, and colleagues have been modified by Todani and associates to include intrahepatic cystic disease.

  • Type I: is a simple cyst that can involve any portion of the CBD.
  • Type II: It is described as an isolated diverticulum arising from the wall of the CBD
  • Type III: They arise from the intraduodenal portion of the common bile duct and are also known as choledochocele.
  • Type IVA: The cysts consist of multiple dilatations of the intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type IVB: These choledochal cysts are multiple dilatations involving only the extrahepatic bile ducts.
  • Type V (Caroli’s disease): It consists of multiple dilatations limited to the intrahepatic bile ducts.

Caroli's disease:

Caroli’s Disease is an autosomal recessive condition multifocal cystic dilatation of segmental intrahepatic bile ducts. According to Todani classification, it is classified as a type V choledochal cyst.  

USG may show dilated intrahepatic bile ducts in these individuals. The beaded appearance of intrahepatic bile ducts on HIDA scan and Central Dot sign on CT are characteristic findings associated with Caroli's disease. MRCP is the investigation of choice.

Treatment options:

  • Type I—excision of the cyst with its mucosa and reconstruction by Roux-en-Y hepaticojejunostomy.
  • In type II—excision of the diverticulum and suturing of the CBD wall can be done
  • Type III cysts represent Choledochoceles, consisting of cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum. As type III cysts are associated with the lowest malignancy risk of any choledochal cyst, endoscopic sphincterotomy followed by surveillance is generally recommended over cyst excision with pancreaticoduodenectomy.
  • Type IV, if the cyst is adherent to the portal vein posteriorly, that part of the cyst wall over the portal vein is left behind. But mucosa of the part should be removed. This is named Lily’s operation.
  • Excision of all cystic tissues and reconstruction of the biliary tree is recommended for extrahepatic biliary involvement as in Type 4B and in case of intrahepatic involvement, an additional segmental resection of the liver may be required which can be removed by hepatectomy.
  • Liver transplantation is the preferred treatment of choice in type IV and type V.

Related Pearl: Classification of Choledochal Cysts

Type

Feature

Type I

The most common choledochal cyst type; it involves only the extrahepatic biliary tree and is generally a fusiform dilation.

Type II

Saccular diverticulum off the common bile duct and may be mistaken for an accessory gallbladder.

Type III

A cystic dilation of the intramural common bile duct, within the wall of the duodenum, known as choledochoceles.

Type IV

Type IVa: Cysts involving the intrahepatic and extrahepatic biliary tree

Type IVb: Multiple cysts limited to the extrahepatic biliary tree.

Type V

Also known as Caroli disease, involve the intrahepatic ducts only.

questions.text: A man was referred for the evaluation of an unsteady gait with weakness of his legs for the past 1 month. He gave a history of similar problems in his brother. Imaging revealed cerebellar hemangioblastomas and bilateral renal masses suggestive of RCC.  Which histological type of this renal malignancy is he most likely to have?
questions.solution:
The clinical features mentioned are consistent with renal cell carcinoma and cerebellar hemangioblastoma which along with the family history points to a diagnosis of von Hippel Lindau’s disease (VHL). Clear cell RCC is the most common type associated with VHL disease. 

VHL disease is inherited as an autosomal dominant trait and is caused by a germline mutation of the VHL gene on chromosome 3p. questions.text:
A chronic smoker with gross painless hematuria was diagnosed with bladder carcinoma. A CT scan showed cancer infiltration into the muscular layer. Which of the following is the most appropriate treatment option for this patient?

TURBT: transurethral resection of bladder tumor

choices.text: Radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection

questions.solution:
The treatment of choice for bladder cancer involving the muscular layer (muscle-invasive bladder carcinoma) is radical cystectomy with lymph node dissection.

Cigarette smoking is the main aetiological factor. Other risk factors include exposure to aniline dyes and schistosomiasis. Patients present with painless gross hematuria and frequency and urgency of urine.

Diagnosis is made using cystourethroscopy. Blue-light cystoscopy is better able to delineate the areas in the bladder with suspicion of malignancy. CT urogram is used to assess the upper urinary tract and the presence of hydroureteronephrosis. It is also used to assess lymph nodal metastases. MRI of the bladder is useful in assessing whether or not the muscle layer of the bladder is involved. 

Depending on the invasion of the lamina propria and muscularis propria layers, the staging and management of bladder cancer varies, as given below:

Non-invasive papillary urothelial cancer Does not involve the lamina propria

TURBT only; patients are followed-up with cystoscopy
Non-muscle invasive bladder cancer Can involve lamina propria, but does not invade the muscularis propria

TURBT followed by postoperative mitomycin C instillation

Multifocal and high-grade tumors may progress to muscle invasive bladder cancer: radical cystectomy or intravesicle BCG should be considered
Muscle invasive bladder cancer Involves the muscularis propria

Radical cystectomy and bilateral pelvic lymphadenectomy with urinary diversion

Radical external beam radiotherapy can be considered in patients unfit for surgery

  • Activating mutations in RAS and PI-3 kinase

questions.text: Which among the following is the most common cause of hydronephrosis detected during prenatal ultrasound?
questions.solution:
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction is the most common cause of hydronephrosis on prenatal ultrasound among the given options.

The Etiology of Antenatal Hydronephrosis:

Aetiology Incidence
Transient hydronephrosis 41–88%
Ureteropelvic junction obstruction 10–30%
Vesicoureteral reflux 10–20%
Ureterocele/ectopic ureter/duplex system 5–7% 
Posterior urethral valve/urethral atresia 1–2% 

In UPJ obstruction, hydronephrosis may be detected on antenatal ultrasound. It can however be transient or mild and resolves on its own.

The causes of UPJ obstruction are:

  • Intrinsic (due to an adynamic or stenotic segment of the proximal ureter) or 
  • Extrinsic (eg. compression by accessory renal arteries). This needs to be corrected primarily.

It is usually associated with renal anomalies and has a 2:1 male-to-female ratio. After birth, re-checking needs to be done and in cases presenting with symptoms of recurrent UTI, palpable flank mass or pain, urinary obstruction, and cases of failure to thrive. If the hydronephrosis is persistent, its severity is graded by the extent of the dilatation of the pelvicalyceal system and parenchymal thickness.

In cases of hydronephrosis, long-standing urine stasis and pressure may damage the kidneys. The renal anatomy and function can be assessed using radioscintigraphy studies. MAG3 (mercaptoacetyl triglycine) which measures tubular function has largely replaced the usage of Tc99- DTPA. The kidneys with decreased function show slower uptake and take a longer time to excrete the tracer. It is even preferred over intravenous pyelogram for assessment of hydronephrosis in newborns and children because IVP images are suboptimal in presence of bowel gas and poor dye uptake in newborn kidneys.

Treatment of intrinsic UPJ obstruction is done surgically if renal function is compromised or bilateral kidneys are involved. In other cases, serial follow-up with ultrasonography is done to assess the spontaneous resolution of hydronephrosis.

questions.text: Which of the following hydrocele occurs due to excessive production of fluid in the sac?
questions.solution:
Secondary hydrocele occurs due to excessive production of fluid in the sac.

A hydrocele is due to fluid accumulation between the two layers of tunica vaginalis. It may be primary or secondary depending on whether it is due to defective absorption of excess formation. Eversion of the sac causes the production of fluid towards the outside which can be absorbed by outer scrotal layers. 

Aetiology of hydrocele:

  • Primary (vaginal)- due to defective absorption of fluid.
  • Secondary hydrocele- due to excessive production of fluid in the sac.
  • Congenital- through connection with the peritoneal cavity via patent processus vaginalis.
  • Due to interference of lymphatic drainage of scrotal structures.

Hydrocele is a swelling that closely encompasses the testis and epididymis making them impalpable. It is possible to get above the swelling in hydrocele to palpate a normal spermatic cord.

Treatment:

  • Jabolay's procedure- eversion of the sac upon itself 
  • Lord's operation- plicating the redundant tunica is done when the sac wall is thin.

questions.text: Which of the following statement about testicular tumour is true?

choices.text: A testicular lump felt separately from the testes is suggestive of malignancy.
Lymphatic spread is to the para aortic lymph nodes.
Microscopic residual disease in the scrotum are Stage III testicular tumours.
Ultrasound is not mandatory in all suspected cases of testicular tumours.

questions.solution:
The lymphatic spread of testicular tumors is to the para-aortic lymph nodes. Inguinal lymph nodes are involved only if the scrotal skin is involved.

A solid testicular lump that cannot be felt separately from the testes is suggestive of malignancy (Option A). The diagnosis of a testicular tumor is confirmed by ultrasound. It can also assess the contralateral testis. Ultrasound is a mandatory investigation in all suspected cases of testicular tumors. (Option D)

Stages of testicular tumors (according to the older staging system of Stages I-IV) are valuable in determining treatment options.

  • Stage I: Tumor is limited to testis
  • Stage II: Microscopic residual disease is present in the scrotum or high in the spermatic cord (Option C)
  • Stage III: Retroperitoneal lymph node involvement
  • Stage IV: Distant metastatic deposits

Note: According to TNM Staging of Testicular Tumor: American Joint Committee on Cancer and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer, depending on the Primary tumor (T), regional lymph node (N), distant metastasis (M), and serum tumor markers (hCG, LDH, AFP) it is staged into stages I, II, III.

Related Pearl: TNM staging of testicular tumour: American Joint Committee on Cancer (AJCC) and Union Internationale Contre le Cancer (UICC)

Primary tumor (T)

The extent of the primary tumor is usually classified after radical orchiectomy (except for pTis and pT4) and, for this reason, a pathologic (p) stage is assigned.

pTx - Primary tumor cannot be assessed

pT0 - No evidence of primary tumor (e.g., a histologic scar in testis)

pTis -  Germ-cell neoplasia in situ

pT1 - Tumor limited to the testis and epididymis without vascular/lymphatic invasion; tumor may invade into tunica albuginea but not tunica vaginalis

pT2 - Tumor limited to testis and epididymis with vascular/lymphatic invasion or tumor extending through the tunica albuginea, with the involvement of tunica vaginalis

pT3 - Tumor invades spermatic cord with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

pT4 - Tumor invades the scrotum with or without vascular/lymphatic invasion

N0 - No regional lymph node metastasis

N1 - Metastasis with lymph node mass ≤2 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, none more than 2 cm in greatest dimension

N2 - Metastasis with lymph node mass, 2–5 cm in greatest dimension; or multiple lymph nodes, anyone mass >2 cm but not more than 5 cm in greatest dimension

N3 - Metastasis with lymph node mass >5 cm in greatest dimension

MX - Distant metastasis cannot be assessed

M0 - No distant metastasis

M1 - Distant metastasis

M1a - Nonregional nodal or pulmonary metastasis

M1b - Distant metastasis at site other than nonregional lymph nodes or lung

S0 - Marker study levels within normal limits

questions.text: FAST investigation is helpful in assessing____________
questions.solution:
FAST is helpful in assessing all of the above including splenic injury, morrison’s pouch and pouch of douglus.

FAST is a rapid diagnostic examination to assess patients with potential thoracoabdominal injuries. It is performed within 2­-4 minutes.

Technique:

  • Patient in supine position
  • 3.5-5.0 MHz convex transducer
  • Five regions may be scanned :
    • subxiphoid transverse view: assess for pericardial effusion and left lobe liver injuries
    • longitudinal view of the right upper quadrant: assess for right liver injuries, right kidney injury, and Morison pouch
    • longitudinal view of the left upper quadrant: assess for splenic injury and left kidney injury t
    • ransverse and longitudinal views of the suprapubic region: assess the bladder and pouch of Douglas

An "extended FAST or eFAST" scan may be performed: left and right thoracic views to assess for pneumothorax and haemothorax.

questions.text: Which phase of damage control surgery focuses on the correction of coagulopathy?
questions.solution:
Phase 2 of damage control surgery focuses on the correction of coagulopathy, hypothermia and acidosis.

Damage control surgery is minimal intervention done to stabilize the patient and do the definite surgery later. It centres on coordinating staged operative interventions with periods of aggressive resuscitation to salvage trauma patients sustaining major injuries. 

It includes an abbreviated laparotomy, temporary packing, and closure of the abdomen in an eﬀort to blunt the physiologic response to prolonged shock and massive haemorrhage.

Phases of damage control surgery are: 

  • Phase I (initial exploration) - this phase consists of an initial operative exploration to attain rapid control of active hemorrhage and contamination
  • Phase II (secondary resuscitation) - this phase focuses on secondary resuscitation to correct hypothermia, coagulopathy and acidosis
  • Phase III (definitive operation) - this phase consists of planned re-exploration and definitive repair of injuries. It typically occurs 48 to 72 hours following initial and after successful secondary resuscitation.

Related Pearl: Damage Control Surgery

Five stages of damage control surgery:

1. Patient selection
2. Control of hemorrhage and control of contamination
3. Resuscitation continued in the intensive care unit
4. Deﬁnitive surgery
5. Abdominal closure

Phases of Damage Control Surgery:

Phase 0: Identification of patient for damage control surgery in emergency room
Phase 1: Emergency laparotomy to stop bleeding and prevent contamination
Phase 2: ICU care for resuscitation
Phase 3: Re-laparotomy for definitive repair

Indications for damage control surgery:

Anatomical

  • Inability to achieve haemostasis
  • Complex abdominal injury, e.g. liver and pancreas
  • Combined vascular, solid and hollow organ injury, e.g. aortic or caval injury
  • Inaccessible major venous injury, e.g. retrohepatic vena cava
  • Demand for non-operative control of other injuries, e.g. fractured pelvis
  • Anticipated need for a time-consuming procedure

Physiological (decline of physiological reserve)

  • Temperature <34ºC
  • pH <7.2
  • Serum lactate >5 mmol/L (normal is <2.5 mmol/L)
  • Prothrombin time (PT) >16 s
  • Partial thromboplastin time (PTT) >60 s
  • Blood transfusion approaching 15 units
  • Systolic blood pressure <90 mmHg for >60 min

Environmental

  • Operating time >60 min
  • Inability to approximate the abdominal incision
  • Desire to reassess the intra-abdominal contents (directed relook)

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)

  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

Related Pearl: NICE Guidelines for CT in Head Injury

National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) Guidelines for Computed Tomography (CT) in Head Injury

Indications for CT imaging within 1 hour of the following risk factors being identified:

  • Glasgow Coma Score (GCS) <12 on initial assessment
  • GCS <15 at 2 hours after injury on assessment in an emergency department
  • Focal neurological deficit
  • Suspected open, depressed, or basal skull fracture
  • More than one episode of vomiting
  • Post-traumatic seizure

Indications for CT imaging within 8 hours:

  • Age >65 years
  • Bleeding or clotting disorders
  • Dangerous mechanism of injury (e.g., fall from a height of >1 meter/5 stairs, road traffic accident)
  • Retrograde amnesia >30 minutes

questions.text: A young man presented with right-sided chest pain and paradoxical respiration after he fell off a tree. The chest X-ray is shown below. Which of the following should be avoided in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the X-ray showing contiguous rib fractures on the right side suggest flail chest. Chest strapping or splinting should be avoided in the management of a flail chest. Mechanically impairing the chest wall movements along with the underlying lung contusions contribute to hypoxia.

A flail chest occurs when 3 or more ribs are fractured in 2 or more places usually due to blunt trauma. It can increase the risk of developing pneumothorax and hemothorax.

Diagnosis is made clinically by observing the paradoxical motion of the chest wall segment during respiration (paradoxical respiration). On inspiration, the loose segment of the chest wall gets displaced inwards and moves outwards on expiration. The gold standard investigation is a CT scan with contrast, with a 3-D reconstruction of the chest wall, displaying the vascular structures.

Treatment consists of oxygen administration, adequate analgesia (including opiates), epidural analgesia, and physiotherapy. Mechanical ventilation is recommended to treat respiratory failure despite adequate analgesia and oxygen.

Related Pearl: Trauma Scoring Systems

Revised Trauma Score  - Total score 0-12 :

  • Glasgow coma scale
  • Respiratory rate
  • Systolic BP

Glasgow coma scale  - Total score 3-15 :

  • Eye-opening
  • Verbal response
  • Motor response

Abbreviated Injury Scale: AIS severity code – 1(minimal severity) to 6 (presumably fatal)

Injury Severity Score – Total score 1 to 75. Calculated summing the squares of the AIS severity codes for the three most severely injured body regions

Score Severity of injury
3-8 Minor
9-16 Moderate
16-24 Serious
>25 Severe/ Critical

  

Mangled Extremity Severity score: Mnemonic - ELiSA

  • Energy that caused the injury, skeletal and soft tissue injury
  • Limb ischemia
  • Shock
  • Patient’s age

TRISS (Trauma and Injury Severity Score) : Mnemonic - IRMA

  • Injury Severity Score
  • Revised Trauma Score
  • Mechanism of Injury (blunt/penetrating)
  • Age

questions.text: A man presents to the emergency with a clean lacerated wound on his forearm. You use the given suturing technique to close his wound. Which of the following statements is false?

choices.text: This technique has the least cut through rate
The wound edges should be everted
Interrupted sutures are used to approximate the wound
After the first bite, the needle should emerge at the of center the wound

questions.solution:
The given image shows interrupted sutures. Horizontal mattress sutures, not interrupted sutures, have the least cut-through rate.

In mattress suture, the initial suture is inserted as an interrupted suture, but then the needle either moves horizontally or vertically and traverses both edges of the wound once again as seen in the picture.

Continuous suture: For a continuous suture, the first suture is inserted in an identical manner to an interrupted suture, but the rest of the sutures are inserted in a continuous manner until the far end of the wound is reached.

Subcuticular sutures: Small bites of the subcuticular tissues are taken on alternate sites of the wound and then gently pulled together thus approximating the wound edges without the risk of the cross-hatched markings of interrupted sutures.

questions.text: Most common type of trachea oesophageal fistula(TEF) is___________

choices.text: A.	Eosophageal atresia with proximal TEF

questions.solution:
The most common type of TEF is proximal esophageal atresia with distal TEF, the proximal blind pouch ends approximately at the distance of one or two vertebral bodies from the distal TEF.

Related Pearl: Types of Tracheo-esophageal Fistula/Esophageal Atresia

Abbreviations:

  • EA: Esophageal atresia
  • TEF: Tracheo-esophageal Fistula

questions.text: Most common GI surgical emergency in neonatal period is__________
questions.solution:
Most common GI surgical emergency in neonatal period is necrotizing enterocolitis.

Necrotizing enterocolitis:

  • Prematurity is the single most important risk factor.
  • Acute abdominal distension, tenderness, and feeding intolerance with gross or occult blood in the stool are hallmark features for NEC.
  • NEC typically occurs in the first few days of life with the initiation of enteral feedings.
  • The pathognomic radiographic feature of NEC is pneumatosis intestinalis. Pneumatosis is composed of hydrogen gas generated by the bacterial fermentation of luminal substrates.
  • Initial management is medical (successful in 50% of the cases), the absolute indication for surgery is perforation.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about mesothelioma?

choices.text: Serpentine asbestos fibers can travel beyond larger airways
More favourable prognosis in epithelial type

questions.solution:
Asbestos exposure is a risk factor for mesothelioma. Serpentine asbestos fibers are large and curly and cannot travel beyond larger airways. However, straight amphibole fibers such as the crocidolite fibers navigate distally into the pulmonary parenchyma.

Other options:

  • Malignant mesothelioma is the most common tumor of the pleura and in 20% cases tumor can arise from the peritoneum.
  • More common in males and most common after 40 years of age.
  • Epithelial type has more favorable prognosis than sarcomatous and biphasic type.

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a double-barrelled aorta seen?
questions.solution:
A double-barrelled aorta is seen in an aortic dissection.

An aortic dissection usually initiates with an intimal tear. In some instances, the dissecting hematoma reenters the lumen of the aorta through a second distal intimal tear, creating a new vascular channel and forming a double-barreled aorta with a false channel.

Acute aortic dissection can be classified by the original DeBakey system, based on location of proximal tear and distal extent of the dissection flap, or the Stanford system that uses location of proximal tear alone. 

DeBakey system:

  • Type I: involves the ascending aorta and extends through the aortic arch and into the descending aorta/abdominal aorta
  • Type II: confined to the ascending aorta
  • Type IIIa: limited to the descending aorta
  • Type IIIb: descending aorta and abdominal aorta

questions.text: Calf tenderness on direct pressure on calf is known as___________
questions.solution:
• Calf tenderness on direct pressure on calf is known as Moses sign, also known as Bancroft's sign.
  • Calf tenderness on forced ankle dorsiflexion is known as Homans sign.
  • Calf tenderness on squeezing the calf from sides is known as Pratt’s sign.

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents to the casualty with complaints of recurrent episodes of syncope and cramping of his left arm. Symptoms mostly occur during his evening badminton practice sessions.  Which of the following is incorrect about this condition?

choices.text: Due to occlusion in the 3rd part of subclavian artery
Distal pulse of the affected side is feeble
CT angiography is used to visualize retrograde blood flow

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario points to a diagnosis of subclavian steal syndrome. In subclavian steal syndrome, the first part of the subclavian artery is occluded.

Subclavian steal syndrome is characterized by the presence of stenosis in the first part of the subclavian artery either due to atherosclerotic changes or emboli. It leads to reversed flow in the vertebral artery causing cerebral ischemia.

Symptoms include dizziness, syncope on arm exercise. Occasionally, distal pulses in the arm of the affected side are found to be feeble.

Investigations include duplex ultrasonography, CT, and MR angiography.

It can be treated by angioplasty, stenting or by extra-thoracic subclavian bypass.
